awd_titl_txt: BBSRC-NSF/BIO:Collaborative Research: Phage host range evolution in spatially structured microbiomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteriophages, the viral parasites of bacteria, are major agents of bacterial death in microbial communities or microbiomes. Previous work has shown that phage host range, the type of bacteria a given phage can successfully infect, can evolve rapidly. This evolution alters the impact that phage have on the composition and function of microbial communities. However, this previous work has focused on bacteria growing in well-mixed conditions while many bacteria in microbiomes exist in aggregations known as biofilms. In biofilms not only is the spatial arrangement of bacteria different, but also their physiology or lifestyle. In this project, which is a collaboration between researchers at the University of Minnesota (US), Dartmouth College (US) and the University of Exeter (UK), research will pair state of the art computer simulations with cutting edge experimental approaches to develop and test theory for predicting the impact that bacteriophage have on bacterial communities. This work will improve our ability to manage microbial communities that are vital for human health, agricultural production, and industrial applications. The project will help train the next generation of scientific leaders by working with postdoctoral researchers and graduate students to carry out the research. Additionally, it will develop teaching modules to engage high school students with the power of computational biology, preparing them to drive the bio-economy of the future.

Despite the abundance of phage and the prevalence of biofilm growth, little is known about the interaction between phage and biofilms. Specifically, there has been a paucity of investigation on how biofilms influence the evolution of phage host range. In addition to developing knowledge on a process that is critical to understanding microbiome behavior, the proposed work will also improve understanding of the evolution of generalist and specialist strategies more broadly. It will connect individual parasite movement to the dynamics of infection waves in heterogeneous environments. Additionally, it will quantify how host heterogeneity that arises from biotic and abiotic factors alters the evolution of parasite host range. The work will integrate a variety of models that span different length scales, with a powerful model system involving Escherichia coli and the bacteriophage T7. The research will develop and test theory to understand the impact of spatial organization, including the abundance of different hosts in a structured environment, the size of patches of hosts and the connectivity of these patches. The research will also develop and test theory to understand the consequences of bacterial matrix production, metabolic heterogeneity of hosts, and host mixing in biofilms. This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Viruses that infect bacteria, known as bacteriophage, play a central role in shaping the composition and function of microbial communities. We found that the number of bacterial species bacteriophage infect is impacted by the ecological interactions between bacteria, and conversely that viruses can alter the ecological interactions between bacteria in predictable ways.

Bacteriophage range from specialists that can only infect a single strain of bacteria, to generalists that can infect many bacterial species. We tested how the ecological interactions between bacteria influence whether specialist or generalist bacteriophage are favored. We first used a mathematical model to demonstrate that when bacterial species compete with each other, generalist phage that can infect all species of bacteria are favored. In contrast when bacteria engage in mutualism and help each other specialist phage that infect only one species are favored. We tested this prediction in an experimental system with interacting strains of Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica. We competed EH7, a generalist phage that can infect both bacteria, against P22vir, a specialist phage that can only infect S. enterica. Experiments supported the findings of our model. Through integrating the model and experiments we found strong support for a generalizable connection between host interactions and the selection on parasite host range.

We also demonstrated that bacteriophage and other intracellular parasites can alter the composition of microbial communities by altering the metabolism of infected cells. We tested the metabolic effects on E. coli of a plasmid, F128, and a bacteriophage, M13, that forms chronic active infections but does not kill its bacterial host. Genome-scale metabolic modeling suggested that both the plasmid and the phage change intracellular demand for different metabolic processes, leading to shifts in the chemical uptake and secretion of infected cells relative to uninfected ones. Experiments supported the model and found that infected cells specifically released more lactate, a compound that plays an important role in the human gut microbiome. We further demonstrated that infected E. coli indeed caused significant changes in the composition of a simple microbial community relative to uninfected E. coli. This work highlights that intracellular parasites alter metabolism in predictable ways, and that these metabolic effects can play a significant role in shaping the composition and function of entire microbial communities.

This grant led to training of junior scientists, and science education for a broad audience. A graduate student and three undergraduates were trained in the Harcombe lab, and two postdocs and a technician were trained in the labs of our collaborators. All mentees were trained in evolutionary ecology, microbiology and computational biology and gained experience engaging in international collaboration. Results from the work were presented at four international conferences, and three departmental seminars. The research was also used to engage about 60 people (students and family members) through a program called CORE (Community Outreach, Retention, Engagement Program). In follow up surveys students rated their overall experience as a 4.8/5 in our lab. Many students stated that they were specifically excited to learn about bacteria-killing viruses.
